We already know that many of these parasites alter host behaviour by manipulating neurotransmitters or via manipulation of neural proteins that regulate the brain. In the case of T. gondii, it encodes an enzyme called tyrosine hydroxylase which is the rate limiting enzyme that converts tyrosine to L-Dopa (which later is converted to the very important neurotransmitter Dopamine). Source: Myself - I'm a neurobiologist that specialises in symbionts that manipulate the brain and behaviour of their host.

It's amazing how much this area of research has exploded over the last few years. The long-held dogma of medical science has been that disease and disorders are determined by the complex interplay between genetics and the surrounding environment. It's now becoming blindly obvious that mutulistic microbial symbionts, which we have evolved with over thousands of years, are a third essential determinant. I'm currently looking at how specific species of gut bacteria influence neurotransmitter biosynthesis and consequently complex behaviours like sleep and attention. It's fascinating.

I've already mentioned this in a related conversation but this area of science has exploded over the last few years. The long-held dogma of medical science has been that disease and disorders are determined by the complex interplay between genetics and the surrounding environment, however it's now becoming blindly obvious that mutulistic microbial symbionts, which we have evolved with over thousands of years, are a third essential determinant. Currently researchers around the globe are determining this by running complex experiments that involve altering common species of gut bacteria. This can be done by removing the gut microbiome completely, removing specific strains, or adding specific stains. The resulting phenotype alterations are extensive and diverse. Some work has even shown that removing essential gut flora can have large impact on fetal development. We also know that altering these microbes can have a direct influence how genes are activated and expressed. Work like this is highly suggestive that our resident microbes play an essential role in our biology.

Oats and other similar foods contain a molecule called beta-glucan. Essentially it helps to reduce LDL cholesterol by binding to it in the intestinal tract, forcing the cholesterol to be excreted as waste instead of being absorbed. The exact molecular/biochemical mechanism on how this occurs isn't completely understood.

You could argue that Toxoplasma gondii was likely parasitic in cats before it evolved to become mutulistic. One example of this is that it doesn't cause detrimental effects to it's primary host (cats), but it causes many complex behavioural changes to it's secondary host (rodents). It is thought that these changes in behaviour reduce the rodent #8217;s ability to evade predators, and make it easier for felines to find, capture, and eat the infected prey, allowing the parasite to enter the cat and complete its life-cycle. Additionally there is an example of a very common bacteria that infects invertebrates called Wolbachia. Strains vary from parasitic to mutulistic. Some can interchange between parasitism and mutulism depending on environmental conditions. For example, a parasitic strain on Wolbachia called wMelPop reduces it's host lifespan by up to half. However, it's nearly genetically identical counterpart, wMelCS, has no parasitic phenotype and can assist the host by provisioning metabolites and increasing fecundity, ie the amount of offspring. Source - Myself. I'm a specialist in Microbial Symbiont-Host interactions, especially symbionts that affect the nervous system. Reading - http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1690701/ http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC23488/

Look into a disorder called [Trimethylaminuria](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trimethylaminuria). It's a recessive disorder (though in some cases can be caused non-genetics reasons like liver dysfunction) that is not terribly common but it would describe many of the problems you're having with odour. Essentially it's caused by the dysfunction of a metabolic enzyme leading to the build up of specific molecule, which in turn causes a bad odour in body secretions (sweat, urine etc.). Unfortunately this is not something good hygiene will fix. If you do have TMAU, which I strongly suspect you do, you will likely be referred to a specialist and be placed on a strict diet that eliminates foods that can cause a build up of FMO3 (the molecule responsible for the odour).

WRITING.TEXT: Bacteria in fly brains makes them do weird things. Lets put it in mosquitoes and see if we can stop them from killing millions of people.

[Professor Scott O'Neill](http://www.npr.org/2012/06/08/154528752/eliminate-dengue-team-has-a-deep-lab-bench) and his team are on the brink of eliminating mosquito borne disease after more than 15 years of painstaking research. His work funded by the Bill amp; Melinda Gates Foundation's Global Health Program, has lead to unbelievable successful control of mosquito borne viruses, like Dengue, by introducing a bacteria to mosquitoes that stops them passing on the virus to humans. The bacteria, known as Wolbachia, has a powerful ability to invade natural populations of insects and alter their reproduction and lifespan. [Learn more about this breakthough research here](http://www.eliminatedengue.com/program)

WRITING.TITLE: Zika virus: Australian dengue researchers may have solution

WRITING.TEXT: Wolbachia infects gt;40% of all invertebrate species, however it is highly unlikely to infect species that do not naturally harbor the bacteria. This is because Wolbachia is vertically transmitted, passed from a female to it's offspring. Female to offspring Wolbachia transfer uses an almost identical mechanism as mitochondria. In fact, it took the research group in the article nearly 10 years to infect one female mosquito, which are not naturally infected with Wolbachia. This was only able to occur by transinfecting the bacteria from a naturally infected host (fruit flies) by micro-injection. Once the female was infected, all of her offspring was infected, and the bacteria could rapidly spread through lab stocks. Additionally, because of the mechanism Wolbachia uses to spread (Cytoplasmic Incompatibility) if actually offers a fitness advantage for the mosquito to be infected, thus quickly overtaking the uninfected population under the right conditions. Watch this [youtube video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1ErcwogWbIA) made by the research group cited in the article to better understand Wolbachia and its utilization as a control agent.

Your husband should be evaluated for an autoimmune disorder. His headaches and additional health issues point towards something more system wide like lupus or MS. Specifically, there are several autoimmune disorders that attack the vascular system and this can lead to chronic headaches, along with other health issues. Also, diabetes is also worth testing for us untreated diabetes can also destroy the vascular system and lead so similar symptoms. His sugar consumption would make this significantly worse.

Do the girl a favor while she's still young and break up with her so she can find and have a normal relationship.

Acute behavioural changes like this are not normal and can be a sign that something is malfunctioning in the brain. It may not be a major problem but it's something that does have the potential to get worse if ignored. These behaviours may indeed stem from stress and exhaustion but it's important to rule out other problems. PM me if you would like to discuss this further.

WRITING.TEXT: Narcolepsy without cataplexy or sleep apnea would be my guess. Go to the doctor and rule out other conditions first and then consider a sleep study.

I'm actually a neuroscientist that is specifically researching sleep. From your description it sounds like your boyfriend has classic symptoms of a hypersomnia disorder such as narcolepsy without catalepsy. He's probably not experiencing enough of one of his essential sleep stages (slow wave sleep or REM sleep) during his normal night time hours and needs to compensate with naps. My money is on hypersomnia. Also, it sounds like he is easily aroused and even being disturbed once during the night is enough to cause an increased sleep need. Get his to a specialist. If he doesn't go, you have every right to be frustrated. I personally have narcolepsy without cataplexy (too much REM and not enough slow wave sleep) and I have to take a 1 hour nap on my lunch break and another when I get home.

If you have seen him, please contact me immediately. See photos: http://imgur.com/a/SdVe6
Thanks! I'm really worried. Hopefully he's just on an amazing adventure
Thank you for the tip. I am willing to try anything!

WRITING.TITLE: UPDATE: LOST CAT - Balmoral / Bulimba
WRITING.TEXT: Last week I posted about my [missing cat](https://www.reddit.com/r/brisbane/comments/5na94e/lost_cat_balmoral_bulimba/) A few people PM'd me asking for an update. I am extremely happy to say that we found him on Sunday! For 5 straight days we looked everywhere within a 2 suburb radius. I even took two days off of work and walked all over Balmoral in the blazing heat. We knocked on doors and hung up posters with no luck. We ended up contacting a feral cat trapper to ask if they had any advice and they suggested we set up a live animal trap in our yard with some stinky food to lure him back. So we drove to the North side and hired a live animal trap, and baited it with tuna. Well it worked like a charm because we caught him 9 hours after setting up the trap! It turns out the little jerk wasn't far at all and was probably having the time of his life. Meaty is currently resting in the aircon at home. We will be keeping an eye on him for a while and have ordered him a special GPS chip for his collar, in case he pulls this stunt again. I'd like to thank everyone for their concern and suggestions! If anyone else loses a cat I would highly recommend setting up a trap as soon as possible!

They aren't cheap but considering we spent over $100 on posters, the cage hire, and petrol, it's probably worth it in the long run. Plus if your cat gets picked up by council, you have to pay a fee to get them out of jail. This is the tracker I bought: http://www.gpspetcollar.com.au/ I specifically ordered this one: http://www.gpspetcollar.com.au/
Yup. He's the loudest, chattiest cat too. We thought for sure we would hear him if we were close. Turns out he wasn't terribly interested in being found.
Here is the track I ended up buying. Some use GPS while others use radio frequency http://www.gpspetcollar.com.au/
I really appreciate the concern! I have learned this past week how kind and helpful people are when it comes to animals.

Absolutely! http://www.gumtree.com.au/s-ad/lutwyche/pet-products/hire-rental-large-humane-animal-trap/1133818334 This one is in Lutwyche but if you search for "animal trap" in Brisbane on gumtree, heaps of places hire them out for weeks or months. What you need to do is set it up somewhere outside of your house that is accessible and also under shelter (like a bush or tree). Place stinky food and a little water at the very back. We used tuna. Drizzle some juice from the tuna can around the trap to lure the cat in. Make sure you remove any food already outside to the cat is more likely to enter the trap. Check the trap twice a day (once in the morning, once late afternoon. Don't hang around the trap too much or you might scare the cat away). It's extremely likely that the cat will only investigate at night so don't assume you'll catch him during the day. Our cat was trapped at 1AM on Sunday morning. Good luck!

One of my girlfriend's is an infectious disease researcher for QLD health. She does a lot of testing and statistics tracking on local STI rates. She tells us all the time how Gonorrhea and Chlamydia rates are absolutely skyrocketing, getting worse every year, because people are using condoms less than they were 10 years ago (probably because people are less concerned with HIV infection). Not surprising, the highest rates are around the three big universities in Brisbane. One University in particular has one of the highest gonorrhea rates in the country. Wrap it up.
It's irrelevant because all three have some of the highest rates in the country. One is just slightly higher.

I'm a USA/Aussie dual citizen. I did my undergrad in the U.S., my PhD in Australia, and have worked and lectured at both Griffith and UQ. Frankly I think both Universities are more or less the same (I can't speak for QUT but I'm sure it's comparable), especially if it's for undergraduate education. I find it laughable when undergraduates at UQ or QUT make fun of Griffith because nobody outside of QLD gives a shit about any of these Universities. But I digress... For graduate school, it depends more on your specialty. Go to the university with the highest rated graduate program in your field. For research, it completely depends on your supervisor, the University doesn't really matter in this case. The only thing that matters for research is publication output. Nobody cares where you did your PhD when you have a Nature paper.

Has she actually been diagnosed with CF or does she just claim to have it? As a neuroscientist, it really annoys me when people claim to have a chronic, life-long disease in order to excuse normal, or slightly above average, levels of fatigue. CF is thought to be a disorder of the mitochondria (the molecules in our cells that pump out energy for the body) and also causes inflammation to the brain and spinal cord. People with CF literally feel mentally and physically lifeless all day, every day. You know when you're really sick with an infection like the flu, how you can't get out of bed or even perform the most mundane task without feeling exhaustion? That's what it is like to have CF. I just find it hard to believe someone with CF is capable of working in a fast-paced environment like a bar. It sounds more typical of a shift work sleep disorder (google it for more info). Most people with CF can't even leave their homes. Sure, she may be fatigued after a long day's work, but until she has an actual diagnosis, I wouldn't let her get away with using it as an excuse. It does sound like you both have very different needs and you should consider what that means for you in the long term.

That's fair and I completely understand why you would be exhausted. I would be too! Just be careful about equating your normal tiredness from being overworked and over-stressed with a disease like CFS.

As I said in another comment, it's totally fair that you're exhausted from working that much. I can completely empathize with that. However most people with active CFS can barely work at all. I'm looking at this from a purely medical/scientific perspective. I totally recommend seeing someone if you think you're still suffering though. Good luck. P.S. I was with a guy who didn't work when I was in my early 20's. That relationship ended after 5 years. I should have left sooner.

You have a bias because you have CFS yourself but the vast majority of people who were diagnosed in the early years of CSF awareness actually have something else. It's not my opinion, it's the opinion of the current, up-to-date scientific research. CSF used to be a blanket statement for a lot of conditions that were not well understood. An updated diagnosis with a rheumatology specialist is important.

Neuroscientist here. You need to see another neurologist and get a second opinion. It sounds like you have a form of agnosia. Perhaps integrative agnosia but there are multiple forms. Get it checked. Specifically bring up agnosia.
Non-essential staff were also sent home with pay. lt;3 thanks UQ
This sounds like classic addict behavior. Ask him to take a drug test. If he refuses, you should assume or at least be extremely concerned that this is the problem.

WRITING.TEXT: You should consider setting up your own trap near your house. You can rent them on gumtree. http://www.gumtree.com.au/s-ad/lutwyche/pet-products/hire-rental-large-humane-animal-trap/1133818334 What you need to do is set it up somewhere outside of your house that is accessible and also under shelter (like a bush or tree). Place stinky food and a little water at the very back. We used tuna to bait our cat when he went missing. Drizzle some juice from the tuna can around the trap to lure the cat in. Make sure you remove any food already outside to the cat is more likely to enter the trap. Check the trap twice a day (once in the morning, once late afternoon. Don't hang around the trap too much or you might scare the cat away). It's extremely likely that the cat will only investigate at night so don't assume you'll catch him during the day. Our cat was trapped at 2AM on Sunday morning. You can read this guide for more information: http://www.missingpetpartnership.org/recovery-tips/trapping-lost-pets/ Good luck!

Also, humane animal traps are one the most successful way to catch a cat since they are almost always hiding near their house, and usually only move around at night. http://www.missingpetpartnership.org/recovery-tips/trapping-lost-pets/

I'm so sorry for your loss :( Two years ago I went through something very similar where I had to put my young cat down because he was born with a birth defect that damaged one of his kidneys. The other kidney had to work extra hard to compensate and he went into renal failure when he was 6 years old. I was devastated and my heart was broken. After a week of grieving, I saw some photos of adoptable cats that were on death row and decided the best way to honor my deceased cat's memory was to give another kitty the chance at life. I ended up adopting two and while I still think about my first cat all the time, it brings me peace and happiness to know that I am giving a wonderful life to my two little fur buddies. Everyone grieves differently but I hope my story gives you something to consider!

I'm a yank and I work at UQ. If you really need to be close to coffee shops and bars, but also be within walking/biking distance to UQ, than West End is going to be your best option. Plus it's basically hipster central in Brisbane. The only issue is that it can be pretty pricey unless you're willing to live in a share house. Taringa, Toowong, Milton and Paddington are also good options.

Look into monofeme. Alternatively, get the copper IUD. It's hormone free and of of the most effective, although your initial price to get it is about $300. However, they can last 5-10 years so you'll make your money back

WRITING.TITLE: 'There was a screw-up': UBC researchers pull paper linking vaccine component to autism
UBC researchers pull paper linking vaccine component to autism after data alleged to be manipulated

WRITING.TEXT: Because there are several forms of mercury. Mercury is a naturally occurring element found in the earth #8217;s crust, air, soil, and water. Two types of mercury to which people may be exposed #8212; methylmercury and ethylmercury #8212; are very different. Methylmercury is the type of mercury found in certain kinds of fish. At high exposure levels methylmercury can be toxic to people. In the United States, federal guidelines keep as much methylmercury as possible out of the environment and food, but over a lifetime, everyone is exposed to some methylmercury. Thimerosal, the type in vaccines, contains ethylmercury, which is cleared from the human body more quickly than methylmercury, and is therefore less likely to cause any harm.
If you stick this bacteria in this mosquito, it can't infect you with Dengue Virus or Zika anymore. Also the bacteria changes insect behavior in a lot of weird ways.

WRITING.TEXT: Try Paddington/Bardon/Ashgrove area. You can find houses for rent here with decent yards for around $500-600/week. Most houses with yards in family areas like this allow pets. I am renting a 2 bedroom house in Paddington and we have two cats and a Belgium Malinois.

I will play devil's advocate due to your Mother's age. Has your Mother been exhibiting other odd behavioural changes? The reason I ask is because signs of Dementia normal occur after age 65 so your Mother is the right age.
Probably not long. There are tons of share houses always looking for new people to fill rooms.
Yes, it's just over 80k. Considering how much education is required plus the extreme hours postdocs typically work, it isn't that great.

Parvo is basically doggy Ebola. Scary stuff! My rescue had parvo before we adopted her and spent 3 months in the hospital where she nearly died. She's now 9 months but she'll never reach her full growth potential because she was so malnourished due to the disease attacking her digestive tract. She'll also likely be on a special diet for most of her life. Parvo is almost always fatal. Get your pets vaccinated, people!

gt; I want to sit in an ivory tower and write papers/engage in discussion for a living. In real life this translates to sitting at a shared desk with 5 other researchers, writing about a super specific topic that your boss predetermines for you, that maybe a handful of people will ever read. The first thing you need to do before going down this long, difficult path is come to terms with the fact that you may never be able to study topics that truly interest you. You'll research what you have to in order to increase your chances of getting future funding. In this current climate, you take whatever jobs you can get.

Thank you so much!

The biggest current problem is constantly exposing ourselves to too much artificial light. We evolved to rise and fall with the sun but it's almost impossible to do this when looking a bright phone or computer screen. It inhibits our normal biological clock so we don't feel tired when we should, i.e. night. At least 1 hour, (I always go for 2) prior to going to sleep, shut everything down, reduce the light in your house (try a low-intensity light-bulb) and do something relaxing like reading. This will allow your brain to naturally transition into sleep. Also, don't go to bed hungry because hungry will actually make our brains actively stay awake. And if you have sleep issues, see a doctor! A lot of sleep-deprived people have an underlining medical issue they aren't aware of.

Consider getting a light-box and do 20 minutes of light therapy when you wake. This could be done while you're eating or getting ready in the bathroom. The natural UV light will trick your brain into believing it's normal day-time hours and it will produce the molecules necessary for staying awake. People also use these for seasonal depression and jetlag http://sleephub.com.au/light-therapy/ Conversely, try to make your room at light-tight as possible. Make sure you're in your dark room at least 1-2 hours before going to bed WITHOUT electronic devices to trick your brain into making sleep promoting molecules.

I have never heard of the banana thing before so I can't comment. As far as food, you need to go to bed without being hungry. You don't need to be overly full, just not hungry. From an evolutionary standpoint, this makes sense because your brain will inhibit your sleep so you can find food and survive.

A lot of people are long sleepers and just need 1-2 hours more than the generally population. On the other hand most people don't know that you can stay asleep and still get poor quality sleep because one of their sleep stages in dysfunctional. Let's say for instance you get a lot of REM sleep but not much slow wave sleep. Even though you might be seeping 9-10 hours, if you don't get enough slow wave sleep you're still going to feel un-refreshed the next morning. This is also why most people don't feel 100% when they take sleeping pills because they generally induce a deep, slow wave sleep and you miss out on all your essential light and REM sleep. And of course there are also problems like sleep apnoea which most people are completely aware of until they see a sleep specialist.

I was in high school during the early day of internet 2.0, including the popular days of message board. My nickname has been Bean since I was a baby so that's what I uses as my username to talk about anime and science, and other nerdy stuff. Changing my username would be like destroying a little part of my very being.
Thank you very much! Your support is appreciated!
I find that sleep is one of those research areas that can be easily transition to because you can study it from so many different angles. It's never to late!

1. Worse, even if you sleep well with a partner. Sleeping alone is always optimal. 2. The mattress doesn't matter as long as you find it comfortable and it doesn't restrict your breathing. Generally people can adjust to any mattress as long as it's comfortable. I personally like memory foam mattresses but that's just a personal preference. 3. As long as you are getting enough sleep for your personal genetic needs it doesn't matter when you sleep. You can listen to your body's normal rhythm and wake up when it feels natural to do so as long as it isn't affecting other aspects of your life. 4. This is controversial but it shouldn't matter. Your brain knows exactly how much sleep it requires and will push you to get that sleep until the sleep deprivation debt is paid off. So if you can achieve all the sleep your brain requires in several broken bouts than you should be fine. 5. I think the absolute main sign (besides the obvious of simply feeling tired) is that your ability to pay attention is affected. Sleep and attention are very connected. For instance, if you spend all day cramming for an examine your brain will require more sleep than usual. If you don't get enough sleep, your ability to pay attention, stay focused, and learn will be extremely impacted. I wish I had a sensory deprivation cocoon but I've not come across one!

WRITING.TEXT: That is the most Barnaby looking pup I have ever seen. Barny for short.
I used to have Turkeys. That's most certainly a female. Males are aggressive as hell.

I think my Mal is broken because she's super chill even to the point of being lazy. She even lays down to eat her food. She did have a very unique start to life so that could potentially be responsible for her laid back behavior. If we ever get another Mal, I have to go into it assuming it will be nothing like our current pup.

She was abandoned at about 3 months by her first owners and was found sick on the street with parvo virus. A rescue group paid for her treatment but she nearly died. She was in the hospital for two months. She basically had little to no contact with other dogs but was constantly surrounded by people. We adopted her at 6 months and now she's completely healthy. Her ears will never stand up because she was so malnourished during her major growth period, but we adore her regardless. She's completely docile and cuddly, but still smart as a typical Mal. She loves nothing more than to just chill with us while we read or watch TV. We do the typical activities that most dogs would require, but she simply doesn't have the explosive energy that is typical for a Mal.
I know! She has such a beautiful soul, I don't know how someone could dump her. She's still whip smart though. The speed at which she learns commands always amazes me.

WRITING.TEXT: We adopted a pure Mal (DNA tested and confirmed) that was found on the street with a deadly case of parvo. She had a really rough start and we had no idea where she was from, but she is an angel baby from heaven. She is the sweetest dog on earth. There is always a risk when taking in a dog with an unknown history but more often than not, they are wonderful.

WRITING.TITLE: Classic double turnover

WRITING.TEXT: Neuroscientist here. This honestly sounds like a mild form of Touretts. These aren't just bad habits - they are a extreme compulsion to complete a physical action caused by the dysfunction in certain areas of your brain. Touretts has a strong genetic component and is strongly related to OCD. It's not just something you can train yourself to stop doing without a medical professional! See a doctor!

I'm a Dr. of neuroscience that specializes in sleep. Your husband has sleep apnea. Seeing as how he's nearly 40, he's probably already done considerable permanent damage. There is a reasonable chance he will develop dementia if complications from the SA don't kill him first. There is still time to reverse some of this damage but it needs to be done ASAP. It's time for you to have a come to Jesus talk.
Not necessarily. My dog looks exactly like this, floppy ears and all, and DNA test revealed she's a GSD x Belgium Malinois. Her thin face suggests she's a Mal cross.

Oh wow, my off the street rescue looked almost exactly like yours when she was a puppy! We DNA tested and found out she's a German Shepherd x Belgium Malinois cross. Betsy as a puppy: https://imgur.com/a/4aeo1ki Betsy Now: https://imgur.com/a/6aYePZR
Hi, fellow early 30's yank here (although I've lived in Brisbane for over 11 years). Shoot me a message if you want to hang.

I moved here from a state in the US that can get down to -30 in the winter and the summers always hovered around the mid 20's. When I moved to Brisbane it took me over 3 years to adjust to the climate. You will sweat more than you realised was possible. My recommendation is make sure you move somewhere with aircon. Carry an insulated bottle of ice water with you whenever you go out. Always wear sunscreen because your skin will take years to adjust to the sun. Keep extra shirts you can change into at work and keep deodorant handy. The good news is that you will adjust eventually. I used to be ghost white, my skin was practically see through and I always burned, never tanned. I'm still pretty white but I achieve a mild tan in the summer and my natural base colour is slightly darker than it used to be. The summer heat also doesn't bother me that much anymore except when I'm sleeping, but that's when having aircon comes in handy. The downside is that anything below 20C feels cold, which is a real bummer since I was so used to extreme cold before. Good luck!
Scientist don't get paid enough to be evil.
